senses.de: The process of examining something closely and carefully.
senses.ex: His private life came under media scrutiny.

Tips.title: Media Usage
Tips.description: The term is often used in news to describe intense media attention.
Tips.example: The politician's speech is under scrutiny by news outlets.

Tips.title: Negative Implication
Tips.description: 'Under scrutiny' can imply problems or issues being looked at.
Tips.example: The company's finances were under scrutiny after the audit.

Tips.title: Seeking Details
Tips.description: Scrutiny implies looking at something very closely.
Tips.example: Her research underwent close scrutiny before publication.

senses.ex: Every aspect of her life was placed under scrutiny.

Tips.title: Academic Research
Tips.description: In academic contexts, means careful, thorough review.
Tips.example: The thesis will face rigorous scrutiny by the panel.

Tips.title: Focused Analysis
Tips.description: Indicates a deep dive into studying all parts of the subject.
Tips.example: Under public scrutiny, the new policy revealed many flaws.

senses.de: The careful checking of a person or something considered for a detailed examination.
senses.ex: His candidate was subjected to a scrutiny by the board in order to test his skill.

Tips.title: Legal Processes
Tips.description: Used when someone's background is checked for qualifications.
Tips.example: The nominee's record is subject to legislative scrutiny.

Tips.title: Skills Assessment
Tips.description: Refers to evaluating competence or suitability for a job.
Tips.example: Applicants' skills were under thorough scrutiny during the interview.

Analysis.wordDefinition:
Analysis refers to examining something in great detail in order to understand its components, functions, and characteristics.

In simpler terms, analysis is about understanding something, while scrutiny is about examining it critically to find faults or mistakes.

Audit.wordDefinition:
An audit is a formal examination of financial accounts or records to check their accuracy and legitimacy. Generally, an audit is conducted by a professional auditor who is independent of the organization being audited.

Audits are often mandatory for businesses and organizations to prove compliance with regulations and to provide transparency to stakeholders.

Unlike an audit, scrutiny may not involve a formal analysis of financial records.

An audit is focused on financial records, while scrutiny can apply to any area that requires thorough examination and evaluation.

While an audit is, in essence, a type of scrutiny, the latter term can refer to a much broader range of examinations.

Examination.wordDefinition:
Examination and scrutiny are both words that refer to looking closely at something, but they are used in slightly different contexts.

Examination usually implies a systematic or formal evaluation of something. For example, a student might take an examination in order to show how well they understand the material they have learned.

In this context, examination often has a sense of being objective, with a focus on measuring abilities or knowledge.

It can refer to a careful examination of something in order to find flaws or problems. For example, a journalist might scrutinize a politician's statements in order to uncover any deceits or hidden agendas.

Both words can be used in a range of contexts, but examination is often associated with academic or professional evaluations, while scrutiny is more commonly used to describe close investigation or critical evaluation.

Inspection.wordDefinition:
Inspection and scrutiny are both related to examining something closely, but there are some subtle differences between the two.

Inspection typically refers to a more general process of checking something to ensure it meets certain standards or requirements.

Inspection is often done in a more cursory manner, looking for obvious faults or problems.

Inspection is a more general process of checking something to make sure it meets certain standards, while scrutiny involves a more detailed and critical examination of something to identify potential problems or weaknesses.

Investigate.wordDefinition:
Investigate means to look into something in order to gather information and find out the truth about it. This can involve conducting interviews, gathering evidence or doing research.

Both investigate and scrutiny are used when studying something in order to gain a better understanding of it.

However, investigation is generally used when looking for evidence to support or disprove a hypothesis, while scrutiny is typically used when examining something in detail to determine its quality or accuracy.

For example, a detective might investigate a crime scene to gather evidence and solve a case. A scientist might scrutinize a piece of data to check the accuracy of the results.

Observation.wordDefinition:
Observation and scrutiny both involve closely looking at something, but there is a subtle difference between the two.

Observation is generally a more casual and general term. It means simply watching or noticing something, often without any specific goal or intention.

Observation is a general term for noticing or watching something, while scrutiny is a more focused and intensive process of examining something in detail.

Both terms can be applied to a wide variety of situations, but scrutiny is typically used in more formal or technical contexts, while observation can be used in more everyday situations.

Perusal.wordDefinition:
Perusal and scrutiny are both words that refer to looking closely at something, but there is a slight difference in meaning.

Perusal means to read or examine something carefully in order to understand it.

This word is often used when referring to documents or texts that need to be reviewed closely. For example, one might say "I gave the contract a thorough perusal before signing it.".

Perusal is more focused on reading and understanding, while scrutiny is more focused on examining and investigating in a critical way.

Review.wordDefinition:
Review means to look over something quickly and give an assessment, usually to determine performance, quality, or overall value.

Review is appropriate when you want to have a general idea about something, whereas scrutiny is appropriate when you want to learn everything in detail.

Study.wordDefinition:
Study refers to a process of learning, understanding, or investigating something through observation, research, or practice.

Study is commonly used in academic and educational settings, but also in other areas such as science, technology, and the arts.

Scrutiny is more focused on analyzing and assessing something in detail, while study is more focused on learning and acquiring knowledge.

Survey.wordDefinition:
Survey refers to a method of collecting data or information from a larger group of individuals.

A survey usually includes a series of questions that are designed to gather information on a specific topic.

Surveys are often used to gather information on public opinion, customer feedback, or a particular product or service.

Scrutiny is examining something really closely, and survey is asking lots of people questions to learn their opinions.
